citation.article-title: Oribaculum catoniae gen. nov., sp. nov.; Catonella morbi gen. nov., sp. nov.; Hallella seregens gen. nov., sp. nov.; Johnsonella ignava gen. nov., sp. nov.; and Dialister pneumosintes gen. nov., comb. nov., nom. rev., Anaerobic gram-negative bacilli from the human gingival crevice.

p.s: Description of Catonella morbi sp. nov.
Catonella morbi, (mor'bi. L. gen. n. morbi, of disease, because originally the organism was isolated from diseased periodontal pockets)
The description below is based on studies of the type strain and seven other strains.
Cells of the type strain from PYG broth cultures are 0.7 to 1.2 μm wide by 1.6 to 4.0 μm long and occur in pairs and short chains.
Central swellings sometimes occur in media containing a fermentable carbohydrate.
Surface colonies on blood agar plates incubated at 37°C for 2 days are 1 mm in diameter, circular, entire, convex, and opaque.
Rabbit erythrocytes are not hemolyzed, and no colonies with a dark pigment are produced.
Serum (10%, vol/vol) enhances growth and usually is required to detect carbohydrate fermentation.
There is moderate turbidity with limited sediment in peptone-yeast extract-serum broth cultures and moderately heavy turbidity with a smooth sediment in PYG-serum broth cultures.
The final pH of PYG-serum broth cultures is 5.0 to 5.6.

The following amounts of fermentation acids (in milliequivalents per 100 ml of culture; mean ± standard error of the mean) are produced in PYG-serum broth cultures: acetic acid, 2.2 ± 0.2; formic acid, 0.6 ± 0.1; and lactic acid, 0.4 ± 0.1.
Abundant hydrogen is detected in the headspace gas of PYG-serum broth cultures.
Additional characteristics of the species are shown in Tables 1 and 2.

The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 34 mol%.
